review.title: OWL: Yet to arrive on the Web of Data?
review.abstract: Seven years on from OWL becoming a W3C recommendation, and two years on from the more recent OWL 2 W3C recommendation, OWL has still experienced only patchy uptake on the Web. Although certain OWL features (like owl:sameAs) are very popular, other features of OWL are largely neglected by publishers in the Linked Data world. This may suggest that despite the promise of easy implementations and the proposal of tractable profiles suggested in OWL's second version, there is still no "right" standard fragment for the Linked Data community. In this paper, we (1) analyse uptake of OWL on the Web of Data, (2) gain insights into the OWL fragment that is actually used/usable on the Web, where we arrive at the conclusion that this fragment is likely to be a simplified profile based on OWL RL, (3) propose and discuss such a new fragment, which we call OWL LD (for Linked Data).

metadata.title: OWL: Yet to arrive on the Web of Data?

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before in the history of the city.

sections.heading: 2. BACKGROUND
sections.text: Before analyzing the use of OWL on the Web, we first recall some relevant features of the semantics of RDF, RDFS and OWL and give a summary of the existing OWL profiles.

sections.heading: 2.1 RDF Graphs and Their Semantics
sections.text: Given the set of URI references U, the set of blank nodes B, and the set of literals L, the set of RDF constants is denoted by C: = U "B" L. We use CURIEs to denote URIs (e.g., owl: sameAs), with the prefixes used in this essay, for example, being found at http: / / prefix.cc /. We often use turtle syntax; e.g., we can use an abbreviation for rdf: type. Finally, V denotes the set of RDF variables that exceed C and we prefix variables with "?." An RDF triple (s, p, o) is a triple of the set of all RDF triples G: = U "B" U "x" C, with s being the subject, p predicate, and o object.

sections.heading: 2.2 OWL and its Fragments
sections.text: OWL 2 is an ontology language that provides advanced schema modeling capabilities that can be used with RDF data. OWL 2 replaces the earlier specification "OWL 1" by introducing new modeling features, additional serializations, updated conformity requirements, and various fixes. If we omit the version number, we mean the current standard OWL 2. Each RDF graph can be considered an OWL ontology and the language of all RDF documents, which can be more complex than individual triples. For example, the triple Ex: a owl: sameAs ex: b. corresponds to the OWL axiom languages (ex: a ex: a ex: a ex: b).

sections.heading: 2.3 OWL Semantics and Reasoning
sections.text: OWL ontologies can be interpreted under two different semantics that agree in important cases: the RDF-Based Semantics (RS) [17] and the Direct Semantics (DS) [26]. As in RDF (S), semantics is defined by specifying a model theory, i.e. by defining valid interpretations for ontologies based on semantic conditions. In RS, these models are based on the representation of OWL axioms as RDF graphs and are therefore considered a sophisticated form of RDF interpretation. In DS, models are based directly on the structure of OWL axioms within the conceptual framework of description logic (which in turn is based on first-order logic).

sections.heading: 3. SURVEY OF RDFS & OWL ADOPTION
sections.text: ON THE WEB OF DATAWe now present an empirical survey of the adoption of RDFS & OWL in the Web of Data. Our survey is based on the Billion Triple Challenge 2011 Corpus, which consists of 2.145 billion quadruples searched from 7,411 million RDF / XML documents through an open crawl that ran over 791 pay-level domains in May / June 2011. (A pay-level domain is a direct subdomain of a top-level domain (TLD) or a second-level country domain (ccSLD), such as dbpedia.org, bbc.co.uk. This gives us our idea of "domain.") This corpus represents a wide sample of the Web of Data.

sections.heading: 3.3 Survey of Datatype Use
sections.text: Let's look at the use of data types in the Web of Data. Apart from the pure words, RDF semantics is a single data type supported under the name RDF-entailment: rdf: XMLLiteral [17]. But RDF semantics also defines interpretations by a data type that allows mapping of lexical data types into a value space.The data type mapping can also be imposed within its value space.These interpretations allow the determination of lexical strands for a data type that refers to different lexical data types that refer to different values, and the data type mapping refers to data type values-values-values-types-types-types-types-types-types-types.

sections.heading: 7. RELATED WORK
sections.text: Here we discuss related studies on the use of RDFS and OWL on the Web (related OWL profiles were covered in Section 2).One of the earliest comprehensive empirical studies of RDF web data was presented by Ding et al. in 2005 [8]. They report on the prevalence of vocabulary terms in over 1.5 million RDF / XML web documents, in which the bulk of the data was described with a friend's friend (FOAF) and Dublin Core (DC) ontologies. The work focuses on the characterization of the structure and distribution of the raw data and not on semantics issues or on RDFS and OWL.Various papers look at the syntactic profiles of OWL ontologies on the Web [2, 38, 7]. Bechhofer and Volz identify and categorize OWL DL constraints through a sample of 201 OWL ontologies.

sections.heading: 8. CONCLUSION
sections.text: We have presented a comprehensive analysis of the current use of OWL on the Web, based on a large sample of RDF / XML documents. We confirmed that OWL has indeed "arrived" in the Web of Data, albeit to varying degrees for different characteristics. Following the principles of Linked Data, we used a PageRank algorithm to assess the importance of individual documents. Our results show that OWL-RL features with a single, triple expression are most important on the Web. An analysis of existing tools confirms that these simple characteristics tend to be better supported. Based on these observations, we defined the OWL-LD profile as a sublanguage of OWL-RL and provided a rules-based reasoning calculation for this. Although motivated by a new analysis of the current ontology documents in the Web of Data, OWL LD is well aligned with the earlier proposals of RDFS-Plus and L2, suggesting that it may be a natural perspective.

referenceMentions.context: Under the initial impetus of the Linking Open Data project – and guided by the Linked Data principles [3] and associated bestpractices – a rich vein of openly-available structured data has been published on the Web using Semantic Web standards.
Although the informative entailment rules for supporting RDFS inferences are relatively straightforward, things like the infinitely many entailed axiomatic triples reduce its practicality [28].
OWL 2 addresses the complexity issue by defining profiles [6]: fragments for which at least some reasoning tasks are tractable.
Further, each profile is a syntactic subset of OWL DL such that RDF data must adhere to certain nontrivial conditions which are commonly not followed in Web ontologies [2, 38, 7].

To address this, OWL further defines three syntactically restricted sub-languages (profiles) of OWL DL called OWL EL, OWL RL and OWL QL [6] (see also Table 2 later for a brief feature comparison).
The current profiles themselves have been inspired by existing approaches: EL for OWL EL [24], DLLite [5] for OWL QL, and Description Logic Programs (DLP) [13] and pD* [35] for OWL RL.

metadata.abstractText: Seven years on from OWL becoming a W3C recommendation, and two years on from the more recent OWL 2 W3C recommendation, OWL has still experienced only patchy uptake on the Web. Although certain OWL features (like owl:sameAs) are very popular, other features of OWL are largely neglected by publishers in the Linked Data world. This may suggest that despite the promise of easy implementations and the proposal of tractable profiles suggested in OWL’s second version, there is still no “right” standard fragment for the Linked Data community. In this paper, we (1) analyse uptake of OWL on the Web of Data, (2) gain insights into the OWL fragment that is actually used/usable on the Web, where we arrive at the conclusion that this fragment is likely to be a simplified profile based on OWL RL, (3) propose and discuss such a new fragment, which we call OWL LD (for Linked Data).
